summary: lysosome-associated membrane protein 1 (LAMP1) and LAMP2 constitute ca. 50% of the proteins in the lysosome membrane and function to maintain the structural integrity of lysosomal compartment. lysosomal rupture is reported to induce cell death through the release of hydrolytic lysosomal enzymes. a few manuscripts have revealed that NA was an important virus segment protein contributing to the virus pathogenesis both in vivo (mice and chickens) and in vitro (MDCK cells), and the sialidase activity of NA expressed in the infected cells was also detected in the lysosome (14). these findings suggest that in addition to its classical mechanism of releasing assembled virus particles from the cell membrane at the late stage of the viral life cycle, the NA of influenza virus may directly bind to L titers are expressed as the 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID50)/ml of supernatant. primary antibodies against LAMP1 (ab24170) (for immunofluorescence), cathepsin K (ab19027), M6PR (ab124767), and cathepsin L (ab58991) were purchased from Abcam (Cambridge, MA) the anti-tubulin AF 488 kit, a peroxisome labeling kit for fixed cells, was procured from Merck (Billerica, MA) the anti-tubulin AF 488 kit, a peroxisome labeling kit for fixed cells, LysoTracker Red DND-99, and ProLong Gold Antifade Mountant with DAPI (4′,6′-diamidino-2-phenylindole) were purchased from Molecular Probe avian influenza virus genes polymerase complex PB1 (GenBank accession no. AAT73504.1), polymerase complex PB2 (GenBank accession no. AAT73545.1), polymerase complex PA (GenBank accession no. AAT70214.1), nucleocapsid protein (NP; GenBank accession no. ABC66772.1), hemagglutinin (GenBank accession no. AAV34704), neuraminidase the transfections of A549 cells were performed with X-treme Gene HP reagents (Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN) according to the protocol provided by the manufacturer. cells were collected and lysed with radioimmunoprecipitation assay (RIPA) lysis buffer. the total protein concentration of each sample was determined with a BCA protein assay kit (TianGen, Beijing, China) the fusion protein was purified with an AKTA FPLC system. equal amounts of LAMP2-Fc or Fc protein were conjugated to new protein A-agarose beads (Santa Cruz) and washed several times with sterile H2O. the relative gene expression levels were calculated using the CT value and normalized to the expression of the human glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase reference gene. all small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) used in the present study were designed and synthesized by Ribobio (Guangzhou, China) after 24 h, the cells were transfected with Lipofectamine RNAiMAX reagent (Invitrogen) and a the method for neuraminidase activity assay in different pH buffers was as described before (18) 5 l of H1N1 or H5N1 influenza A virus suspension were incubated with 5 l of 4 mM 2′-(4-methylumbelliferyl)--d-N-acetylneuraminic acid sodium salt hydrate (4-MU-Neu5Ac; Sigma-Aldrich) at 37°C for 30 min. images were analyzed using confocal laser scanning microscopy (FV-1000; Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) at least 64 pictures were continuously obtained by the confocal microscope automatically. the images were assessed with ImageJ software (National Institute of Health, Bethesda, MD) to label cellular lysosomes, the cells were incubated with 300 nM LysoTracker Red DND 99 (Molecular Probes) in fresh medium for 30 min at 37° the cells were then washed three times with PBS, harvested with trypsin-EDTA, and washed with 1 ml of PBS. the cells were then fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and analyzed by FACSAria II cytometer (BD, San Jose, CA) influenza viruses isolated from human in 1999 and avian influenza virus H5N1 isolated from chickens in 2004 were used in the present study. 0.05 indicates statistical significance, and P 0.01 indicates high significance. the NA (IT-003-021M2) antibody was purchased from Immune Technology (Foster City, CA), the NP (C01321M) antibody was purchased from Millipore (Billerica, MA), the TFEB (H00007942-M01) antibody was purchased from Abnova (Taipei, Taiwan), and horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated secondary antibodies and luminal reagents for immunoblotting were purchased from Santa Cruz HEK293T and H1650 cells were propagated in DMEM. MRC-5 cells were propagated in Eagle minimum essential medium. all of these cells were cultured in indicated medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum. the full-length cDNAs encoding human LAMP1, LAMP2A, and avian influenza virus NA (Jilin) A/Jilin/9/2004 (H5N1) were amplified by using PCR from a cDNA library of A549 cells or cells infected with H5N1 influenza virus. all of these gene products were verified by DNA sequencing (Invitrogen, Beijing, China) proteins were transferred onto a nitrocellulose filter membrane. membrane was stripped with stripping buffer (1% SDS, 25 mM glycine [pH 2.0]) and then incubated with another primary antibody. cDNA was synthesized from 1.5 g of total RNA with a high-capacity cDNA reverse transcription kit. the relative gene expression levels were normalized to the expression of the human glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase reference gene. cells were seeded at 3 105 cells/well in 12-well plates. after 24 h, the cells were transfected with lipofectamine RNAiMAX reagent. the siRNA sequences for LAMP1 were 5′-CAAUGCGAGCUCCAAdTdT-3′ and 3′-dTdT GUUACGCUCGAGGUUUUU-5′. a549 cells were grown on coverslips in 24-well plates. at the indicated time points after virus infection, the culture supernatant was removed and the coverslips were washed three times with PBS. the cells were then fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min, penetrated with 0.2% Triton X-100 for 5 min and blocked with 10% goat serum for additional 30 min. in the rescue experiments, peramivir (30 g/ml) or zanamivir (30 g/ml) was added 1 h before viral administration or at the indicated time points. in the siRNA knockdown group, A549 cells were transfected with siRNA as described before. 50 l of 50% protein A-agarose beads (Santa Cruz) was added to the samples. the mixture was incubated for an additional 2 h at 4°C. the beads were then washed extensively five times with TBS buffer. lysosomes in primary cells human tracheal epithelial cells cell in cells infected with the live H5N1 virus found that treatment with the NA inhibitors could ameliorate lysosomal rupture. these data demonstrate that the NA inhibitors peramivir and zanamivir could reduce the deglycosylation of LAMPs and protect from lysosomal rupture induced by influenza virus infection. avian H5N1 influenza virus NA protein induces lysosomal rupture. this may play an cells were treated with PBS or the NA inhibitors peramivir (30 g/ml) and zanamivir (30 g/ml) 1 h before H1N1 or H5N1 virus infection and 4 h postinfection. the NP-positive nucleus was analyzed by confocal microscopy. the percentage of NP-positive nuclei were determined using ImageJ software. lysosome cell death could occur after lysosomal membrane permeabilization and leakage of lysosomal hydrolases. lysosome rupture could be induced by the deglycosylation of LAMP1 and LAMP2 after influenza virus infection. lysosome functions are critical maintaining mouse survival. the molecular basis for this phenomenon remains unknown. we have observed more severe LAMPs deglycosylation caused by H5N1 virus NA than by H1N1 virus NA. a higher enzyme activity for H5N1 influenza virus NA was detected.
